headline: Global investors stay 'uber-bullish' but warn companies are overinvesting
summary: MILAN, Feb 17 - Global investors are increasingly worried that ‌companies are overinvesting, just as ‌market sentiment remains “uber‑bullish” and further asset gains ​look harder to achieve, Bank of America’s monthly fund manager survey showed on Tuesday. The poll of 162 ‌managers overseeing $440 ⁠billion found cash balances rose to 3.

headline: A Top New Concern for Fund Managers: Companies Are 'Overinvesting'
summary: With AI spending surging, a record share of fund managers now think companies are overinvesting, according to Bank of America's latest monthly survey. The consensus among investors is that capital expenditure is "too hot right now," BofA analysts wrote.

content.title: A Top New Concern for Fund Managers: Companies Are 'Overinvesting'
content.summary: With AI spending surging, a record share of fund managers now think companies are overinvesting, according to Bank of America's latest monthly survey. The consensus among investors is that capital expenditure is "too hot right now," BofA analysts wrote.

headline: BofA Survey Shows Investor Worry Over Capex Race at Record High
summary: While investors participating in the survey are the most bullish they’ve been since June 2021, about 35% warned that corporations are overinvesting, the highest proportion seen in data going back two decades, strategist Michael Hartnett wrote in a note.  Record levels of capital expenditure are expected this year, with the four biggest US technology companies together forecasting spending of about $650 billion in 2026.  Microsoft Corp. plunged the most in almost six years on concerns about how long it might take for investments to pay off, while Meta Platforms Inc. jumped more than 11% after it revealed its ambitious AI spending plans.

content.title: BofA Survey Shows Investor Worry Over Capex Race at Record High
content.summary: While investors participating in the survey are the most bullish they’ve been since June 2021, about 35% warned that corporations are overinvesting, the highest proportion seen in data going back two decades, strategist Michael Hartnett wrote in a note.  Record levels of capital expenditure are expected this year, with the four biggest US technology companies together forecasting spending of about $650 billion in 2026.  Microsoft Corp. plunged the most in almost six years on concerns about how long it might take for investments to pay off, while Meta Platforms Inc. jumped more than 11% after it revealed its ambitious AI spending plans.

headline: AI Spending by U.S. Companies Has Fund Managers Looking Overseas for Stocks
summary: Artificial-spending concerns and bubble risks are making overseas stocks more attractive, says a BofA survey.

headline: Big Bank CEO pay surged by $45 million in 2025
summary: Big bank CEOs saw their 2025 compensation rise by a collective $45.3 million from the year before to $258 million, according to regulatory filings and Yahoo Finance’s tally.

content.title: Big Bank CEO pay surged by $45 million in 2025
content.summary: Big bank CEOs saw their 2025 compensation rise by a collective $45.3 million from the year before to $258 million, according to regulatory filings and Yahoo Finance’s tally.

headline: JPMorgan's Q4 Loan Trajectory: Where Did Expansion Show Up?
summary: JPM's Q4 2025 loans hit $1.49T as wholesale and card balances led the surge, and an Apple Card issuer deal could add about $20B.

content.title: JPMorgan's Q4 Loan Trajectory: Where Did Expansion Show Up?
content.summary: JPM's Q4 2025 loans hit $1.49T as wholesale and card balances led the surge, and an Apple Card issuer deal could add about $20B.

headline: Dive Deposits: Want a bigger raise? Don’t be a long-tenured CEO
summary: Bank of America’s $41 million payday for Brian Moynihan shows two trends: Newer big-bank CEOs received larger raises. And Moynihan’s 2025 compensation may have been held back by a comparatively better 2024.

content.title: Dive Deposits: Want a bigger raise? Don’t be a long-tenured CEO
content.summary: Bank of America’s $41 million payday for Brian Moynihan shows two trends: Newer big-bank CEOs received larger raises. And Moynihan’s 2025 compensation may have been held back by a comparatively better 2024.

thumbnail.caption: Brian Moynihan, Chairman and CEO of Bank of America, speaks at an Economic Club of Washington event on February 25, 2025 in Washington, DC.

headline: Big Bank CEOs received serious pay bumps in 2025
summary: CEOS from the biggest banks — JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC), Morgan Stanley (MS), and Goldman Sachs (GS) — all earned at least $40 million in 2025, their total pay increases rising by $45.3 million. Yahoo Finance Senior Bank Reporter David Hollerith examines these pay increases reported by major bank executives as the Trump administration lifted banking regulations last year. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

Yahoo Finance Senior Bank Reporter David Hollerith examines these pay increases reported by major bank executives as the Trump administration lifted banking regulations last year.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

headline: Berkshire issues last 13F of Buffett-era, enters new media name
summary: Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE:BRKa) released its 13F for the quarter ended December 31, 2025, after the close of trading on Tuesday, offering a revealing look at how the firm is positioning its massive equity portfolio at a historic transition. With Warren Buffett officially retiring as chief executive officer on December 31, 2025, at age ninety-five, the filing carries added weight. It marks the last of the Buffett era and the first under successor Greg Abel, who assumed day-to-day leadership. The c

headline: Berkshire Buys New York Times Stock; Sells Apple, Bank of America, Amazon In 4Q
summary: Berkshire Hathaway  continued to trim its stake in  Bank of America  and  Apple  in the fourth quarter and it initiated a new holding in  New York Times  buying five million shares of the newspaper publishing company, according to a 13-F filing after the close of trading Tuesday.  Berkshire also sold most of its holdings in  Amazon  com in the period.  Berkshire reduced its stake in Bank of America by 51 million shares, or about 9%, to 517 million shares, while trimming its interest in Apple by 4%, or 10 million shares, to 227 million.

content.title: Berkshire Buys New York Times Stock; Sells Apple, Bank of America, Amazon In 4Q
content.summary: Berkshire Hathaway  continued to trim its stake in  Bank of America  and  Apple  in the fourth quarter and it initiated a new holding in  New York Times  buying five million shares of the newspaper publishing company, according to a 13-F filing after the close of trading Tuesday.  Berkshire also sold most of its holdings in  Amazon  com in the period.  Berkshire reduced its stake in Bank of America by 51 million shares, or about 9%, to 517 million shares, while trimming its interest in Apple by 4%, or 10 million shares, to 227 million.

headline: Shopify Posts 31% Revenue Growth, Guides Low-30s Expansion
summary: Q4 revenue reached about $3.7B with a 19% free cash flow margin as analysts reiterate bullish ratings and price targets up to $192.
